pros: Starbucks offers great benefits and perks to partners, even if you only work part time you are eligible. Obviously you get free coffee and a free food item when you work which I've really enjoyed. I appreciate that Starbucks genuinely lives up to its values of caring for partners and customers. Starbucks also ethically sources it's food and coffee. I love that their healthy food options don't sacrifice flavor - all their paninis are tasty.
cons: Due to the customizable nature of Starbucks menu, it takes longer to make many of their drinks than a place with a smaller menu would take. Thus, lines are long and wait times are long but it's a rhythm you'll learn. The impetus to both connect with customers and get them their order and have them out the window (in the drive through) in a set amount of time is hard to achieve. The learning curve is steep for the amount of time you have to learn before being tossed into the fray. This is less relevant for quieter stores - mine is always slammed and I only work 2 days a week so it took me a long time to feel comfortable on all positions.

review_title: Not the worst but definitely not good
pros:
Health insurance to part-time employees

cons: Everything else, Starbucks is a complete hive mind. They will say that they offer great benefits, but they won't actually pay you well enough to live life with those benefits. They will consistently cut labor and push you harder and harder to work until you have nothing left. They (higher ups, the store managers are just doing their best with the crap they're given) would rather work you into the ground and have you suffer a mental breakdown (you literally hear about it happening to someone every day) and quit to replace you with someone new than actually take care of the employees that work their tails off for them. They are greedy and a horrible employer. Just because they're not as bad as other employers (McDonald's or Walmart) does not mean they're good by any stretch of the imagination. Also customers are horrible and pretentious. They're orders get more complicated with every passing day.

job_title: Barista, Server, Hostess, and Cook in Crosshands, Wales
pros: fab place to work for sure
cons: for from where my lived travel was difficult

pros: As a full-time employee you can get a lot of benefits offered to you. 401K, stocks, discounts at different stores, health insurance, a free pound of coffee every week and more. You get a paid meal with your shift and a paid beverage on your breaks. Lots of reasons to keep the job, that's why you see partners who have been there for 15 years+. The more you get along with your team, the better the job is. If you show you work hard and well, they will promote you.
cons: You are overworked and sometimes it feels like you aren't paid enough. Each store is ran a little different, which is expected when you work for a new manager. There are plenty of customers who will try to make you feel less of a human throughout the years.

pros: Naturally food service jobs suck, but Starbucks is definitely the best place to be for food service. We made above minimum wage and we received a wide range of health benefits. In addition, when a close family member of mine died and I left town to attend his funeral and make final arrangements for his possessions after his death, I received bereavement pay for the entire time I was gone (approx. 3 weeks). Although for me this was my college part-time job, I noticed that Starbucks offers plenty of opportunities for advancement within the company and rewards hard-working baristas. I appreciated seeing good shift managers move on to become store managers. Whenever my friends ask for recommendations for transitional jobs, I never hesitate to recommend Starbucks. My personal favorite perk was the unlimited free beverages during my shift and one free food item per shift - and the 30% partner discount whenever I wasn't working.
cons: Didn't like new District Manager, but my Store Manager and the previous District Manager were awesome. I think this one woman was just an anomaly.

review_title: Great benefits. But overall work experience will be dependent on the specific store you're placed at
pros: Great 401k option, free stocks, free meal and drinks when working and 30% on days off. Paid vacation hours/sick hours after you've started accumulating them. Discounted online education and healthcare. Coworkers generally tend to be friendly. Can actually love and appreciate your store manager and supervisors and enjoy working with 99% of people at your store and not dread going to work even if you have a 6hr+ shift.
cons: Can be subject to favoritism by supervisor/managers, have your hours secretly reduced by a salty manager, and be subjected to unfair work environments e.g. short-staffing causes a 3-person job to become a 2-person job (very big difference esp when its busy). The company likes to say they care a lot about their employees, but most of that isn't true on the individual level just because of the sheer number of employees. How you're treated majority of the time will be determined by your supervisors (and by your store manager if youre a supervisor).

review_title: Nice place to work with nice benefits
pros: I worked at two locations and really enjoyed the people I worked with and the benefits we received, such as our weekly markouts and discounts. I know my coworkers really appreciated the health insurance plans they offered as well as the opportunity to get an ASU degree.
cons: The customers can be the worst part of the job. Depending on the manager/ supervisor(s) you may have to cater to customers who make you feel inferior. As much as I loved crafting drinks and working with my coworkers, I had to choose to move on from Starbucks due to months of constantly being berated by customers and being talked down to. Additionally, I was scheduled to close all the time as a full time college student. I understand the limited solutions to this issue, because of the effects of covid on staffing and store hours, but my shift would last the whole day, and I would end up clocking out around 1 or 2 hours after my scheduled time since we would be too busy to pre-close and had too much to do after close. After a full day of getting yelled at by customers, prepping and cleaning the whole store, I would be too physically and mentally drained to study or apply to internships for school.

pros:
Free coffee
Customers are usually nice
cons: The culture is terrible. It’s like you’re in high school. It’s cliquey, people are more worried about creating drama then doing their job, and there is extreme inequality on how people are treated. My boss kept all eating of reaching out above her hidden but now I know how to report the store. It’s insane. Some shifts can yell at everyone, never be in dress code, yell AT THE MANAGER, harass me even AFTER I QUIT, and never even face any consequences. If she did she had the courtesy of it being private. But the manager has confided that she doesn’t write her up because that shift would lose her job. However I have a rumor that I’m not in the store even though there are cameras that can prove otherwise but I’m written up in the middle of the lobby in front of customers and all co workers. And that was COMMON. I wasn’t allowed to ask to not be scheduled with the shift that always yelled at everyone and harassed me even though I have PTSD and was heavily suicidal at the time. Which my disability was disclosed to the manager. I have a laundry list of what’s wrong here but the thing is privately the manager will say she understands that she sees these problems etc but as soon as you want something done about it, suddenly she’s never seen any issues. I would rather work for literally anyone else over that. I’m reporting this store now that I have a new job because honestly I wouldn’t doubt that there are some few specific people that would’ve tried to undermine my efforts at getting a new job even before reporting but much more after. Just don’t work there. Especially if you want hours. A lot of people get less than ten a week. Some no hours at all. They hire so many people because the turn over rate is so high. If you’re thinking about working here, just don’t. Especially if you have a disability or less than extremely perfect mental health. I could go on but I don’t have time to write a book

review_title: So much respect for this company!!
pros:
To start off, I had no expectations of Starbucks when I began working there. I would 100% recommend working here.

- Actual breaks (10 minute break for an under 4 hour shift. 1 30 minute lunch for 4-6 hour shift and 1 30 min + 1 10 minute break for 6+ hour shift). 
- Free food and drinks!!
- HEALTHCARE!! This is a HUGE advantage. If you even work 2 hours/week, you're eligible for healthcare provided by Starbucks! All paid time and full time workers are eligible!
- Extremely flexible schedules!
- Good pay with tips!
- Customers love the baristas because we make coffee! I've met the sweetest people while working at Starbucks and have gotten even $20 tips from people
- All baristas and managers are known as 'partners' so managers aren't seen as above
- free education!!! Starbucks is teamed with Arizona State University to provide college degrees for baristas!
- Managers actually care for the baristas
- No double shifts!!
cons: - Shifts are broken into morning, afternoon, and evening, so people cant work from like 8-4 or something. It's generally between 5-7 am until noon. noon until 6 pm and anywhere between 4-6 pm until closing.

review_title: Neutral: Not great but not entirely horrible
pros:
-It's fun to learn how to make all the different drinks. It seems daunting at first, but most are made in very similar ways, but the main difference is the ingredients used.
-Free drink and food item per shift 
-free spotify for being a partner
-As long as you work 20 hrs a week (for a certain period of time) you will be able to qualify for their college program.
cons:
-Need to be able to adjust to a fast-paced environment so may not be best as a first job.
-Hours may not be set in stone. I personally tried to always volunteer to be part of the opening team due to the fact I also had a second job I worked at night, but I know the kids in high school that I worked with were unhappy about their hours/ schedules. 
-This will be a bit odd to put in a con, but dealing with certain customers is exhausting. I've had customers order drinks they didn't understand and when I would ask if they meant to order X instead, I would be berated. Also have been screamed at because we didn't have something in stock. I could go on and on, but if you have a hard time dealing with rude people, would not recommend this job.
-Doesn't have the greatest HR. I had an incident at my store that involved a shift lead that was harassing/ intimidating me during a shift that escalated to where I no longer felt safe working that shift and walked out. Emailed my manager (they were on vacation), my DM, and reached out to HR without any response from anyone. Nothing was resolved or even addressed. I ended up having to take care of things on my own and tried to have a conversation with the lead since my manager refused to bring up the topic other than that my request to not work with the lead was denied.

review_title: Great benefits, pretty good pay, horrible management
pros: This is a stellar high school/college job, as they have a ton of benefits such as insurance, college, 401K's, etc, and if you catch a good store with a good manager it can be a good place to stay for awhile. Pay is usually about minimum wage, plus some extra money per week in tips.
cons: You get run through the ringer emotionally, it's an incredibly fast paced environment and you have to deal with unpleasant people and conflict almost every day. My store in particular has had a lot of insane events happen and we call the cops on customers weekly, with little to no support from higher up management. It's nearly impossible to be heard whether you're a barista, or a shift and they will work you into the ground if you let them.

Most baristas make minimum wage, and they are stingy about raises.

pros: Free pound of coffee/box of tea a week, employee discount (30%), free drinks while working. LGBT friendly, progressive, able to express yourself with hair, some piercings, and a more relaxed dress code then a few years ago.
cons:
THE CUSTOMERS. Starbucks culture encourages you to let customers walk all over you in order to "make the moment right". For many stores and managers this means giving rude customers whatever they want and letting them belittle you, while you cant do anything about it. Only at the end of my time at Starbucks did I finally get a manager who told off the rude customers. This included customers who were racist towards my coworkers. 

Also, Starbucks likes to make it seem like they care about their employees more than they actually do. Its a public image thing, I guess. It all felt very fake to me, telling us how much they care and were there for us while also doing what I mentioned above, creating annoying, ridiculous drinks that mess up your flow on bar, and being stupidly stringy with health insurance.

Tik-Tok drinks also became my worst enemy the last year I worked there. The fact that Starbucks doesn't prevent customers from making nonsense, disgusting drinks with 20 modifications is a shame. That's how I can tell that it's all about the money to them, and the pattering on about how much they care about us is empty.

Yes, I'm bitter.
